question.title: Destructively delete every other element from a linked list

node.contents: I don't know java, but it seems clear that when it reaches '3' it can't eliminate '4' because the last conditional evaluates as false. To solve the problem, just eliminate that conditional.

node.contents: Thank you, this makes sense now. For some reason, I wasn't thinking about the fact that there are already base cases testing for null and the extra conditional isn't needed.

node.contents: It's because, when you are at 3, you do nothing (because link.next.next is null).

astNode.text: It's because, when you are at 3, you do nothing (because link.next.next is null).

node.contents: At that point, you should set link.next to null. This is achieved automatically when you just get rid of the entire if-statement.

node.contents: After you connect first and third, you go to third and try to get fort and fifth, since fifth is null, you can't get it, but it is ok to set next of third to null, so your last if should be deleted and everything will be fine.
